quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Applied Forces & Friction Problems
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2 Quiz 6: Multi-Stage Motion with Constant Forces
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A $2.0\ \text{kg}$ block is initially at rest on a rough, level surface. A constant pushing force is applied horizontally, causing the block to travel $4.0\ \text{m}$ in $3.0\ \text{s}$. At the $3.0\ \text{s}$ mark, the pushing force is removed, and the block slides an additional $2.5\ \text{m}$ before coming to rest. Assuming the frictional force is constant throughout the motion, what is the magnitude of the constant pushing force?
questions.explanation: Phase 1 (force + friction): $a_1 = 2d_1/t_1^2 = 8/9 \approx 0.8889\ \text{m/s}^2$, $v = a_1 t_1 \approx 2.667\ \text{m/s}$. Phase 2 (friction only): $a_2 = -v^2/(2d_2) \approx -1.422\ \text{m/s}^2$, $f = m|a_2| \approx 2.844\ \text{N}$. Pushing force $F = m a_1 + f \approx 1.778 + 2.844 = 4.622\ \text{N}$.

questions.question: A different $2.0\ \text{kg}$ block starts from rest on a rough surface. A constant force moves it $4.0\ \text{m}$ in $3.0\ \text{s}$, then the force is removed. The block slides $2.5\ \text{m}$ more to rest. What is the frictional force acting on this block?
questions.explanation: Phase 1: $a_1 = 8/9 \approx 0.8889\ \text{m/s}^2$, $v \approx 2.667\ \text{m/s}$. Phase 2: $a_2 = -v^2/(2d_2) \approx -1.422\ \text{m/s}^2$, so frictional force $f = m|a_2| = 2.0 \times 1.422 \approx 2.844\ \text{N}$.

questions.question: A $1.5\ \text{kg}$ crate is initially at rest on a rough floor. A constant pulling force is applied horizontally, causing the crate to travel $5.0\ \text{m}$ in $6.0\ \text{s}$. The force is then removed, and the crate slides an additional $3.0\ \text{m}$ before stopping. Assuming constant friction, what is the coefficient of kinetic friction?

A $0.80\ \text{kg}$ hockey puck is initially at rest on a rough, level surface. A constant horizontal force is applied, causing it to travel $12\ \text{m}$ in $4.0\ \text{s}$. The force is then removed, and the puck coasts an additional $8.0\ \text{m}$ before coming to rest. Assuming constant friction, what is the magnitude of the applied force?

A $3.0\ \text{kg}$ box is initially at rest on a rough surface. A constant force pushes it horizontally $2.0\ \text{m}$ in $5.0\ \text{s}$, then the force is removed. The box slides $1.0\ \text{m}$ more before stopping. Assuming constant friction, what is the friction force?

A $0.60\ \text{kg}$ model car starts from rest on a rough track. Its motor provides constant force for $3.0\ \text{m}$ (taking $7.0\ \text{s}$), then power cuts off and it rolls $2.0\ \text{m}$ to stop. Assuming constant rolling friction, what is the motor force?

A $2.5\ \text{kg}$ sled starts from rest on snowy ground. A constant pull force moves it $8.0\ \text{m}$ in $10\ \text{s}$, then is removed. The sled slides $4.0\ \text{m}$ more before stopping. Assuming constant snow friction, what is the friction force?

A $1.2\ \text{kg}$ block starts from rest on a rough table. A constant force acts for $1.5\ \text{m}$ (taking $4.0\ \text{s}$), then is removed. The block slides $0.75\ \text{m}$ more before stopping. Assuming constant friction, what is the applied force?

A $4.0\ \text{kg}$ cart starts from rest on a rough track. A constant push moves it $6.0\ \text{m}$ in $8.0\ \text{s}$, then the push stops. The cart coasts $3.0\ \text{m}$ to rest. Assuming constant friction, what is the push force?

A $5.0\ \text{kg}$ package starts from rest on a rough floor. A constant pulling force moves it $10\ \text{m}$ in $12\ \text{s}$, then is removed. The package slides $6.0\ \text{m}$ more before stopping. Assuming constant friction, what is the pulling force?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered multi-stage motion analysis with applied and frictional forces.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of kinematics with constant acceleration phases.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Practice separating motion into distinct phases with different net forces.
scoreMessages.0: Review kinematics equations and Newton's second law for multi-stage motion.
